message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The echocardiogram findings suggest Tetralogy of Fallot, which can present with poor feeding, excessive perspiration, cyanosis, and tachycardia. Double-inlet ventricle with unobstructed pulmonary flow can also present similarly. Infracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous return, Severe Ebstein anomaly, and Pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum would have different echocardiogram findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical features and echocardiogram findings are consistent with Tetralogy of Fallot. Among the options, only Double-inlet ventricle with unobstructed pulmonary flow can present with similar clinical features, such as cyanosis and poor feeding. However, the echocardiogram findings for Double-inlet ventricle with unobstructed pulmonary flow are different from those of Tetralogy of Fallot, with a single ventricle that has 2 atrioventricular valves instead of 2 ventricles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical features and echocardiogram findings suggest a diagnosis of Tetralogy of Fallot. Among the options, Double-inlet ventricle with unobstructed pulmonary flow can also present with poor feeding and hypercyanotic spells (bluish discoloration of skin and mucous membranes due to decreased oxygen).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical features described in the question suggest a possibility of truncus arteriosus. Among the options, only Double-inlet ventricle with unobstructed pulmonary flow can also present with poor feeding, excessive perspiration, tachycardia, and cyanosis due to low oxygen saturation. Infracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous return presents with hypoxia, and severe Ebstein anomaly and pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum do not typically present with poor feeding and excessive perspiration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the echocardiogram findings suggests Tetralogy of Fallot, which is characterized by a single arterial trunk with overriding of the ventricular septal defect, and can present with poor feeding, sweating, and cyanosis. Among the options, only Double-inlet ventricle with unobstructed pulmonary flow can also present with similar features, including cyanosis and tachycardia, due to mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical features of poor feeding, excessive perspiration, and cyanosis suggest probable cyanotic heart disease. Among the options, only Double-inlet ventricle with unobstructed pulmonary flow can present similarly, with tachypnea, tachycardia, and cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical features in the infant are consistent with congenital heart disease, specifically Tetralogy of Fallot. Among the options, only Double-inlet ventricle with unobstructed pulmonary flow can present with similar clinical features, such as cyanosis and tachycardia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical features of poor feeding, excessive perspiration, and cyanosis are suggestive of congenital heart diseases. Among the options, only Double-inlet ventricle with unobstructed pulmonary flow presents with a single arterial trunk and defects in the interventricular septum, similar to the echocardiogram findings in the given case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant has symptoms of tachypnea, cyanosis, and poor feeding, which are common features of congenital heart diseases. The echocardiogram reveals a single arterial trunk, an interventricular septum defect, and overriding of the trunk, which suggests Tetralogy of Fallot. However, among the options, only Double-inlet ventricle with unobstructed pulmonary flow can also present with similar clinical features such as poor feeding, cyanosis, and tachypnea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical features and echocardiogram findings suggest Tetralogy of Fallot, which is characterized by a single arterial trunk, interventricular septal defect, and overriding of the aorta. Among the other options, only Double-inlet ventricle with unobstructed pulmonary flow can present with similar clinical features, such as poor feeding, excessive perspiration, and cyanosis.
